answers.answer: If you are a medical student and are aware of the years and years of training (college, medical school, internship, residency and fellowships) that go into training a Doctor of Medicine WHY would you go to a non-MD non-physician optometrist.?I would see an ophthalmologist MD for an evaluation before committing to an extended and expensive medical work-up.And good luck in your medical career.JCH MD

question: I went to the optometrist today for a routine eye exam and was also told I had retinal hemorrhage.  The doctor said the most common causes are hypertension and diabetes and that such systemic diseases should be excluded so I am seeing my GP tomorrow.  I am a medical student and we often practicing taking blood pressure on each other, so I think HTN can reasonably be excluded already.  I am also an active 28 year old female, taking my multivitamins and trying to be conscious about how I eat (though my BMI is about 28) so diabetes doesn't make a lot of sense either.  I do get migraine with aura and incidentally, have had 3 in the last month (which is extremely rare for me...I usually get that many in a year).Does this sound like a familiar pattern of symptoms?  Can retinal hemorrhage be brought on by bouts of high stress (like the first month back to school after a lovely relaxing summer?).  Are there sometimes idiopathic causes and its truly nothing to worry about?Thank you,Samba
title: causes for retinal hemorrhage
